quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: One of the most effective ways to create a big leap in your career and something that worked really well for me a few years ago is to create a personal board of directors, a trusted peer group where you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice, and just gut check how you're thinking about your work, your career, and your life.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable career-growth tactic: intentionally build a trusted peer group to pressure-test decisions and accelerate development.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: With Sidebar, senior leaders are matched with highly vetted, private supportive peer groups to lean on for unbiased opinions, diverse perspectives and raw feedback.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete mechanism for implementing the “personal board of directors” idea via structured peer matching and feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Built to work with Gmail and Outlook, teams who use Superhuman spend half the time in their inboxes respond to twice the number of emails and save over four hours a week.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Specific productivity claims that quantify the potential impact of improving email workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: That's over a month of save time per year.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that translates weekly time savings into an annualized, easier-to-grasp benefit.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: With Superhuman, you can split your inbox into streams or VIPs, team members and emails from your favorite products to reduce context switching and make sure you never miss an important email.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Practical workflow advice: organize inbound work to reduce context switching and improve reliability.

quotes.topic_title: Pat leave and new-parent maxims
quotes.text: First one, I would say a little bit better every day. No matter how many books you read and how much money ouster you consume, there's nothing like actually doing it. It's a physical thing being a new parent. Getting a little bit better every day, giving yourself permission to be like that didn't go great and that's okay. That's number one.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A practical improvement loop that emphasizes learning-by-doing and self-compassion over over-consuming advice.

quotes.topic_title: Pat leave and new-parent maxims
quotes.text: Number two, don't over extrapolate from the early days. The fourth trimester is a real thing. These babies come out. They're not fully baked. They can't even support their own heads. If you try to extrapolate everything, the next 18 years are going to be the first 18 days, it's going to be sobering. Keep that perspective. They develop so much every week, part of the fun.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A counter-bias reminder to avoid projecting short-term chaos into long-term expectations, using the “fourth trimester” as a mental model.

quotes.topic_title: Pat leave and new-parent maxims
quotes.text: Then the third thing, which I got advice from this from a good friend is like you got to fully get into it as a parent. There's nothing that replaces. Actually, you got to change the diapers. You got to do the feeds. When they're up, even though they can't talk, you got to talk to them. You got to listen to what they're saying and just be fully present near the moment.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A presence-first operating principle: hands-on participation and attention are non-substitutable inputs.

quotes.topic_title: Pat leave and new-parent maxims
quotes.text: I realized for myself, and then basically at full digital detox. You saw how long it took for me to reply to your emails. I was like, "Throw the devices away. Just fully with our daughter, [inaudible 00:06:34], and our family."
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A concrete tactic (digital detox) to enforce presence by removing default distractions and reclaiming attention.

quotes.topic_title: Foursquare memories and consumer-to-B2B pivots
quotes.text: I think there's something actually where you learn more from the things that don't fully work out or don't quite achieve what you wanted to achieve.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Highlights a practitioner mindset: treat partial failures as higher-signal learning opportunities than clean wins.

quotes.topic_title: Foursquare memories and consumer-to-B2B pivots
quotes.text: You actually have a feedback loop where you get a lot of negative signal about like, "Okay. That didn't work. That didn't work. What can I actually learn, take away from that?"
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Frames iteration as a tight negative-signal feedback loop—useful for product teams designing experiments and postmortems.

quotes.topic_title: Foursquare memories and consumer-to-B2B pivots
quotes.text: I think in hindsight we were a little bit mistaken to believe that the idea that the atomic unit would be a person talking about a place that they're at and you have to have a physical place to tie it to versus a person sharing a moment or an experience that they're having in the world.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A memorable “atomic unit” mental model for product design: choose the right core object of sharing/engagement or you lose the market.

quotes.topic_title: Foursquare memories and consumer-to-B2B pivots
quotes.text: Yeah. I think the feedback to you get from our people willing to pay for the product that you're building is so much faster than can I build a large-scale consumer business and when they hope to have enough reach to then slap ads onto it.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Contrasts B2B vs consumer by speed of monetization signal—useful when deciding business model and go-to-market strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Working with strongly opinionated product founders
quotes.text: I would say to folks in general, if you're joining company and the CEO does the role that is your functional area of expertise, it's probably the area where you'll learn the most because they're hopefully world class at it. But also, one will you'll be the most frustrated at times because you're going to feel like you have less agency. You should just know that going into it.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Sets expectations for working under a product-minded founder: high learning paired with lower autonomy, which helps practitioners choose roles and manage frustration.

quotes.topic_title: Working with strongly opinionated product founders
quotes.text: The first is, I think as much as possible, I think maybe we'll talk about this a little bit later as well, is getting to the point where you have alignment on the principles for what it means to build a great product of that company. Not just about if the intuition and tasting gut, but how do you distill that to principles that become the language of the company so that everybody else can start thinking through a similar frame or similar lens when you're designing a product.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Actionable method for reducing founder-driven churn by codifying product taste into shared principles and a common decision language.

quotes.topic_title: Working with strongly opinionated product founders
quotes.text: The short version I think that works the best is almost like a U-curve where the X-axis is time and the Y-axis is level of involvement.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable involvement model for founders: heavy early alignment, autonomy in the middle, and deep engagement at the end.

quotes.topic_title: Working with strongly opinionated product founders
quotes.text: I think what we would wind up doing with Stewart at Slack, for example, is we would get the entire development team, engineers design product, user research and Stewart together in a room and we almost do a bug bash together. The idea was like, "We're doing it all together. We're trying to make the best product possible, making great softwares really messy and we're all trying to clean up the mess together."
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Concrete practice for late-stage founder involvement that turns subjective critique into collaborative, high-signal product refinement.

quotes.topic_title: Slack product principles: host mindset and simplicity
quotes.text: I think for us, they were really about unpacking just the mission, which for Slack is making people's working lives simpler, more pleasant, more productive. That's the mission of the company. The question is how does software help do that? That's what the principles or their answer.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A practical method for deriving product principles: start from the mission and translate it into how the software should behave.

quotes.topic_title: Slack product principles: host mindset and simplicity
quotes.text: The first is be a great host, which is all about that level of craft, the relentlessly saving people's steps. If you're, let's say, a host at Airbnb, it's like putting clean towels on the bed. No one has to wonder "Are these for me?" That type of foresight.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A memorable principle that operationalizes “craft” as anticipating user needs and removing uncertainty through small details.

quotes.topic_title: Slack product principles: host mindset and simplicity
quotes.text: But often actually, that owner's delusion that someone else will care as much about the software that you built as you do, prevents you from actually making something that's simple, comprehensible, understandable.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that deep product passion can backfire by making teams overestimate user motivation and tolerance for complexity.

quotes.topic_title: Slack product principles: host mindset and simplicity
quotes.text: There's a saying we also have, which is more clicks can often be okay.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Challenges the common “reduce every click” optimization heuristic by prioritizing clarity and confidence over raw efficiency.

quotes.topic_title: Slack product principles: host mindset and simplicity
quotes.text: But I actually think in a lot of software when it's not transactional, helping people understand what they're doing, giving them confidence, helping them have trust in the steps, we've seen that that can actually be a better experience.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for UX tradeoffs: add steps when they increase user understanding, confidence, and trust—especially outside transactional flows.

quotes.topic_title: AI lessons from Google to Slack
quotes.text: I think a couple things come out as ... I guess the principles that we've used over the years, back then at Google, one of the big ones, was that the promise of the UI has to match the quality of the underlying data, which is to say ... I think this is actually one of the failings of the various LMs right now is they all appear supremely confident even when they're completely hallucinating.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A core product principle for AI: calibrate UX confidence to model/data reliability to avoid misleading users.

quotes.topic_title: AI lessons from Google to Slack
quotes.text: I think that's going to be something that people are going to have to work on a lot, which is to figure out how to be not so faultless, to acknowledge when you're not sure, because otherwise, it undermines the trust people have in the system.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for reducing hallucination harm: design the system to express uncertainty to preserve trust.

quotes.topic_title: AI lessons from Google to Slack
quotes.text: Using a lot of transparency about where the data comes from so people can actually build credibility and the tools is really important.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A practical trust-building tactic: show provenance so users can judge and verify outputs.

quotes.topic_title: AI lessons from Google to Slack
quotes.text: Then I think making sure that as you're designing the products that you have virtuous cycles that are naturally part of the product experience where you can get training data as a byproduct of people naturally using the software and then can make the model that you're building behind the scenes smarter, more accurate, more predictive.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A methodology for sustainable AI products: embed feedback loops that generate training data from normal usage.

quotes.topic_title: AI lessons from Google to Slack
quotes.text: A classic example of that would be Netflix back in the day, their rating system, they actually have a feedback loop from their customers then make the system better at predicting.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Concrete example of a virtuous data loop: explicit user ratings improving recommendation accuracy over time.

quotes.topic_title: Slack’s AI vision: organizational knowledge assistant
quotes.text: There was our whole strategy, there's four parts. Then part number four, which was a joke at the time, was then do magic AI stuff on top.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A memorable example of explicitly reserving space in a product strategy for future-step capabilities once the tech catches up.

quotes.topic_title: Slack’s AI vision: organizational knowledge assistant
quotes.text: that knowledge is in Slack, but it's sometimes hard to reach and I think these technologies can make that possible.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A practical framing of AI’s value: not creating new knowledge, but making existing organizational knowledge accessible at the moment of need.

quotes.topic_title: Slack’s AI vision: organizational knowledge assistant
quotes.text: There's no point in trying to design that right now because that's not actually going to be delivering on the promise.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian product-design reminder to avoid designing for a “north star” experience until the underlying capability can actually fulfill it.

quotes.topic_title: Slack’s AI vision: organizational knowledge assistant
quotes.text: Our version of that has always been that you open up Slack and suddenly instead of having to read through dozens of channels or find these mentions that magically Slack could just tell you in order that you would care about a summary of all the interesting things that have happened and then let you dig in if you want to your very own personal chief of staff who knew everything that you cared about and read everything that you could read.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A clear north-star vision for an AI knowledge assistant: prioritized summaries plus optional drill-down, like a personal chief of staff.

quotes.topic_title: How Slack structures AI teams and experiments
quotes.text: I mean the unfair answer is a hybrid of the two, which is to say we have a central machine learning and search team.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Introduces a practical org design pattern for AI: combine a central platform team with distributed product ownership.

quotes.topic_title: How Slack structures AI teams and experiments
quotes.text: What we've done is because the space is evolving so quickly, literally every month, the capabilities are evolving, the risks and tradeoffs are evolving a ton.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Explains why AI org structure must adapt to rapid change in capabilities and risk profiles.

quotes.topic_title: How Slack structures AI teams and experiments
quotes.text: What we want to do is actually spin up a couple different teams that are focused on prototyping, using that common infrastructure but in specific directions that are all a little bit different.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Recommends parallel prototyping teams on shared infrastructure to explore multiple AI bets simultaneously.

quotes.topic_title: How Slack structures AI teams and experiments
quotes.text: Just like every product team is responsible for their own mobile roadmap. They don't outsource it to someone else.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Memorable analogy arguing AI should become a standard responsibility embedded in each product area over time.

quotes.topic_title: How Slack structures AI teams and experiments
quotes.text: But I think today when things are moving so quickly, you actually want a little bit of a more ad hoc, flexible approach to move quickly and that's what we're doing.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to temporarily favor flexibility and speed over rigid team structures during fast-moving AI shifts.

quotes.topic_title: Complaint Storms: critiquing products to find friction
quotes.text: The idea a little bit was how do we help as a team look at the software that we build with fresh eyes, because we've been set at Slack for a long time.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Frames the core purpose of Complaint Storms as a deliberate mechanism to regain beginner perspective on a product you know too well.

quotes.topic_title: Complaint Storms: critiquing products to find friction
quotes.text: What we were realizing, especially for people trying to build Slack for the next million customers, the people who have never used Slack before, it was becoming increasingly hard to have empathy for what their usage of Slack would look like.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Highlights the empathy gap that emerges when builders become extreme power users, especially when targeting new-to-category customers.

quotes.topic_title: Complaint Storms: critiquing products to find friction
quotes.text: What we started doing with these complaints storms and idea was really simple, which is we'd get a team together often Stewart myself would also join and we'd actually start off with other products first in adjacent spaces and we'd say, "Okay. As a group we're going to go through the customer journey from the moment you land on the website through, let's say it's a workplace product, getting your first account going, getting the first couple of users on board, getting to the point of value.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, repeatable ritual: run a group walkthrough of the end-to-end journey, starting with adjacent products to build critical muscles.

quotes.topic_title: Complaint Storms: critiquing products to find friction
quotes.text: We're going to do it on one screen. Someone's going to project and then people are going to fill in every issue, everything that's confusing, every pain point, not bones, but ways in which if you didn't care about the software, you don't work on it, what would actually confuse you? What would stop you in your tracks?
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Provides the operational method and lens: a shared-screen critique focused on where indifferent users would get blocked.

quotes.topic_title: Complaint Storms: critiquing products to find friction
quotes.text: Whenever a team I think either gets stuck or feels like they reach a dead end in a direction is doing complaint-storms about the product area that they're in or using adjacent products just to get inspiration.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Positions Complaint Storms as a practical unblocker when teams stall—either by critiquing their own area or borrowing ideas from adjacent tools.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritizing fixes: portfolios and Customer Love Sprints
quotes.text: No. I mean, more broadly, I think the way that we think about, or us to think about our roadmap for any feature team at Slack is that it's a portfolio and it's meant to be a portfolio that's diversified a couple different ways.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Introduces a portfolio model for roadmapping that encourages deliberate diversification rather than a single linear priority list.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritizing fixes: portfolios and Customer Love Sprints
quotes.text: I think one is you want to diversify things that are meant to be new capabilities versus making the thing you've already built a little bit better every day. Similar to parenting.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Gives a memorable axis for balancing roadmap work between innovation and continuous improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritizing fixes: portfolios and Customer Love Sprints
quotes.text: Are there things that are meant to be risky that you aren't sure are going to work but might have a lot of upside versus things that are known bets.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Adds a second diversification axis—risk vs. certainty—to help teams avoid over-indexing on safe work.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritizing fixes: portfolios and Customer Love Sprints
quotes.text: What we'll wind up doing often is have a team do a two-week customer love sprint, almost like a hackathon, but with that burndown list of what we think is the lowest effort, highest impact changes that we can make to generate more love from our customers and whatever that feature areas.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Describes a concrete, time-boxed methodology for shipping many small, high-impact improvements without derailing the broader roadmap.

quotes.topic_title: Prioritizing fixes: portfolios and Customer Love Sprints
quotes.text: I would think teams that work on very user facing products do it at least once a quarter.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Provides a specific cadence benchmark practitioners can use to operationalize continuous product polish.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing delight: DNA, hiring, and customer feedback
quotes.text: I think that DNA we're trying to build a consumer grade experience that just happens to be for work is really ingrained in the company.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A clear product-quality bar/mental model: treat B2B software like consumer products to drive delight.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing delight: DNA, hiring, and customer feedback
quotes.text: It's also a big part of how we hire.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Highlights hiring as a primary lever for sustaining product delight, not just process or roadmaps.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing delight: DNA, hiring, and customer feedback
quotes.text: From the very early days people used to do CE shifts if you worked in products so that you can actually figure out what's frustrating, what's confusing.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A concrete operational practice: require product orgs to rotate through customer support to build empathy and uncover issues firsthand.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing delight: DNA, hiring, and customer feedback
quotes.text: We have a really great pipeline for getting the insights from the CE team of what are the obstacles, the pain points, the most frequent complaints into the hands of the product teams to be able to prioritize, to figure out, yeah, not all these are going to move a given metric. They might not achieve something for the business.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Describes a feedback-loop methodology and a counter-metric stance: prioritize customer pain even when it doesn’t map cleanly to business metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing delight: DNA, hiring, and customer feedback
quotes.text: But collectively, I think the way that Slack thinks about competition is we obsess it about customers. We build something they'll love enough to tell their coworkers and the rest takes care of itself.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A memorable go-to-market/product strategy: win via customer obsession and word-of-mouth rather than direct competitive feature-chasing.

quotes.topic_title: Competition: HipChat, Discord, and Microsoft Teams
quotes.text: I think the through line for all of them I would say is still the max that we have in trailing, which is we're customer obsessed but competitor aware.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A crisp competitive strategy mantra that prioritizes user value while still monitoring rivals.

quotes.topic_title: Competition: HipChat, Discord, and Microsoft Teams
quotes.text: I think Slack came along and I think they had a couple of innovations. One was they had a great mobile experience that synced across every client. Search actually worked and then they brought a lot of the best parts of consumer messaging into the workplace like the emoji and reactions and all those bits.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Concrete examples of differentiated product bets (mobile sync, working search, consumer UX patterns) that created an adoption wedge.

quotes.topic_title: Competition: HipChat, Discord, and Microsoft Teams
quotes.text: I think it turns out that if you're 10X better on a couple of those axes, then you can see a huge change in behavior.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A practical product-growth heuristic: focus on being dramatically better on a few key dimensions to drive switching.

quotes.topic_title: Competition: HipChat, Discord, and Microsoft Teams
quotes.text: That winds up being a completely different audience to build for than communities.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A segmentation mental model that warns against assuming “chat” products serve the same user/job across contexts.

quotes.topic_title: Competition: HipChat, Discord, and Microsoft Teams
quotes.text: We like to say that Slack is this connected tissue that makes all the rest of your tools that much better.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A memorable positioning statement for platform/ecosystem strategy—win by integrating and amplifying other tools.

quotes.topic_title: Innovation at scale: bigger boulder bets and incubation
quotes.text: The idea there is that it's really easy to fall into the trap of just constant incrementalism.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A warning against KPI-driven feature work that can crowd out meaningful innovation.

quotes.topic_title: Innovation at scale: bigger boulder bets and incubation
quotes.text: We have this mental metaphor that we talk a lot about getting to the next hill.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A simple strategic mental model for pushing past local optimization to reveal bigger opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Innovation at scale: bigger boulder bets and incubation
quotes.text: I think structurally the way we've approached it is that we've over time freighted new teams from scratch that incubated in a new area before the area mature.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A concrete org design tactic: create new teams to incubate emerging bets rather than forcing them into existing structures.

quotes.topic_title: Innovation at scale: bigger boulder bets and incubation
quotes.text: I think when we have those teams, I think it's important to just give them space to run, to give them ... get a gel free card for maybe the normal process of, "Okay. Our planning quarterly reviews" and make it feel something that is the pace of learning is what matters.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Operational guidance for incubation teams: optimize for learning speed over standard planning cadence.

quotes.topic_title: Innovation at scale: bigger boulder bets and incubation
quotes.text: How fast are you prototyping, how fast are you learning from users and then getting to do that publicly and pilot and then get something to launch that's amazing, blows people away.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A practical set of execution metrics for zero-to-one work: prototype speed, user learning, piloting, and high-impact launches.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Thousands of fast-growing companies like Gusto, Com, Quora, and Modern Treasury trust Vanta to help build, scale, manage, and demonstrate their security and compliance programs and get ready for audits in weeks, not months.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete social proof plus a clear time-to-value claim practitioners can use as a benchmark for compliance readiness.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: By offering the most in-demand security and privacy frameworks such as SOC 2, ISO 27,001, GDPR, HIPAA, and many more, Vanta helps companies obtain the reports they need to accelerate growth, build efficient compliance processes, mitigate risks to their businesses, and build trust with external stakeholders.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Summarizes a practical compliance strategy: map work to specific frameworks to drive growth, risk reduction, and stakeholder trust.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 5,000 fast-growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2 and these other frameworks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific adoption and automation data point that quantifies how much compliance work can be systematized.

quotes.topic_title: Rituals: reading tweets and staying grounded in feedback
quotes.text: at all hands we'll often wind up taking specific tweets that people had about the product and Twitter.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable ritual teams can adopt to bring real-world user feedback into internal forums.

quotes.topic_title: Rituals: reading tweets and staying grounded in feedback
quotes.text: Sometimes they're really heartwarming like customer love, but often it's just the meanest, most frustrating complaints that people have.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Highlights the value of intentionally exposing teams to both praise and harsh criticism to stay honest about the product experience.

quotes.topic_title: Rituals: reading tweets and staying grounded in feedback
quotes.text: It's honestly meant for us to just have a pulse on, we're at people actually saying and feeling in the wild and not thinking too seriously, but keeping that sense of ...
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: Frames the practice as lightweight sentiment-sensing rather than over-analyzing, which makes it easier to sustain as a habit.

quotes.topic_title: Rituals: reading tweets and staying grounded in feedback
quotes.text: I think that the distance you have from your users as your user base gets more and more diverse and larger I think can make it harder to actually develop the product because you're not designing for yourself anymore.
quotes.speaker: Noah Weiss
quotes.context: A memorable warning about scale: as users diversify, teams must deliberately close the empathy gap to keep building the right thing.
